questions.text: What is the following logo used to indicate in biomedical waste management?
questions.solution:

Explanation: 

  • Biohazard or Biomedical waste or Biochemical waste includes chemicals used in labs, pathogens, viruses, bacteria, and other microorganisms that pose health risks.

questions.text: Which color-coded container is used for disposing of infectious biomedical waste, such as contaminated dressings or swabs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Yellow

Explanation:

As contaminated dressings or swabs are infectious, they fall into the yellow category.

Colour

Waste Type

Type of bag or container to be used

Method of disposal

Yellow
  • All infectious waste.
  • Human anatomical waste.
  • Animal anatomical waste
  • Soiled waste (contaminated with blood, body fluids, dressings and swabs, blood bags).
  • Expired or discarded medicines
  • Chemical waste.
  • Microbiological and other clinical laboratory waste.
  • Yellow coloured non chlorinated plastic bags.
  • Incineration
  • Plasma pyrolysis
  • Deep burial

Red
  • Contaminated waste (recyclable): Tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles), vacutainers and gloves.
  • Red coloured non chlorinated plastic bags.
  • Autoclaving or microwaving/hydroclaving, and then sent for recycling (not to landfill).

Blue
  • Glassware: Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampoules except those contaminated with cytotoxic waste.
  • Metallic body implants.
  • Cardboard boxes with blue coloured markings.
  • Disinfection or autoclaving/microwaving, hydroclaving and then sent to recycling.

White
  • Waste sharps including metals: Needles, syringes with fixed needles, scalpels or any other sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts.
  • Puncture proof and leak proof containers.
  • Auto or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding and mutilation or encapsulation.

No components of PPE are discarded under blue (Option A) or white (Option D) categories.

questions.text: Which of the following chemical agents is used in the management of a mercury spill?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sodium thiosulfate

Explanation: 

Sodium thiosulphate reacts with mercury ions to form a complex that is less toxic and less soluble and hence used in the management of mercury spill

Management of mercury spill:

  • Switch off fans
  • Remove anything metallic from one's body
  • Wear PPE
  • Never broom
  • Use 2 X-ray films or 2 plastic boards to collect the mercury
  • Dispose of decontaminated material in leak-proof, sealable plastic bags and dispose as mercury waste
  • Clean floor with sodium thiosulphate

questions.text: A rural clinic generates biomedical waste daily with no nearest biomedical waste treatment facility nearby. What is the most appropriate method for disposing of biomedical waste in this situation?

choices.text: Use of disinfectants and dispose with municipal waste

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Deep Burial

 

Explanation:

Deep Burial:

  • Indication: No common biomedical waste treatment facility (CBWTF) is available nearby.
  • 2 metres deep.
  • Common practice in PHCs.
  • Biomedical waste should not be disposed of in regular landfills (Option A) due to its hazardous nature and potential for environmental contamination.

 

The use of disinfectants and dispose with municipal waste (Option C) does not ensure proper treatment of biomedical waste and may lead to contamination of municipal waste streams, posing risks to waste handlers and the public.

questions.text: A patient involved in an accident has sustained multiple injuries and a large amount of blood spills onto the floor. Which of the following is used for managing body spills?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 10% sodium hypochlorite solution used

Explanation: 

Body spill refers to bodily fluids being accidentally spilled or released onto a surface, common in healthcare settings.

Sodium hypochlorite is highly effective as a disinfectant against a broad spectrum of pathogens, including bacteria, viruses, and fungi.

Body spill management:

  • 0.1% sodium hypochlorite solution used.
  • 10% sodium hypochlorite solution used for larger spills.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false ?

choices.text: The best way to dispose of sputum is incineration
Inertization includes mixing waste with cement and other substances before disposal
Contents of red bag should be incinerated
Screw Feed Technique is contraindicated for radiological waste

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Contents of the red bag should be incinerated.

 

Explanation:

The contents of red bags should not be incinerated as they contain cadmium which is explosive.

 

Inertization:

  • Mainly used for Pharmaceutical waste.
  • Mixing waste with cement and other substances before disposal. (Option B)
  • Mixture includes:
    • 65% pharmaceutical work.
    • 15% lime.
    • 15% cement.
    • 5% water.

 

Screw feed technique:

  • Biomedical waste + Auger + Heat + Rotate.
  • Weight reduced by 20-25%.
  • Volume reduced by 80%.
  • Used for infectious waste and sharp waste.
  • Contraindicated for radiological waste, cytological waste and pathological waste. (Option D)

 

Incineration:

  • High-temperature, dry oxidation process that reduces organic and combustible waste to inorganic, incombustible matter.
  • Reduction of waste volume (85 - 95%) and weight (30%).
  • The best way to dispose of sputum is incineration as it falls under infectious bodily waste. (Option A)
  • Incineration is not suitable for
    • Pressurized gas containers.
    • Reactive chemicals
    • Halogenated plastics (PVC).
    • Waste with high mercury (eg thermometer)
    • Sealed ampoules containing heavy metals and sharps.
    • Contents of the red bag, as they contain cadmium which is explosive. (Option C)

questions.text: In a home quarantine setting for a COVID-19 patient, which coloured bags should be used for disposing of biomedical waste according to the specified protocol?

choices.text: Red bag for used masks and tissues, yellow bag for rapid COVID-19 antigen test kits
Yellow bag for used masks and tissues, black bag for general waste
Black bag for used masks and tissues, yellow bag for rapid COVID-19 antigen test kits
Red bag for used masks and tissues, black bag for general waste

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Yellow bag for used masks and tissues, black bag for general waste

 

Explanation:

COVID-19 patients quarantined at home should use yellow bags for biomedical waste including used masks, tissues, and other items contaminated with body fluids.

 

Segregation of Biomedical Waste

  1. COVID-19 waste disposal:
    • Category 1 (Yellow Bags): Used masks, gloves, caps, goggles, shoe covers, disposable linen (bed sheets, pillow covers), etc., from isolation wards and quarantine areas.
    • Category 2 (Red Bags): Used COVID-19 test kits, contaminated PPE, disposable medical devices, sharps, etc.
    • Category 3 (Black Bags): General waste like food wrappers, paper, and other non-infectious items from quarantine areas.
  2. Segregation of COVID-19 waste at Point of Generation:
    • Biomedical waste and general solid waste should be segregated immediately where it is generated, such as in wards or isolation rooms.
  3. Segregation of COVID-19 waste in Home Quarantine:
    • COVID-19 patients quarantined at home should use two colored bags:
      • Black Bag: For general waste like food wrappers, paper.
      • Yellow Bag: For biomedical waste including used masks, tissues, and other items contaminated with body fluids.

questions.text: Which term refers to the study and practice of improving the genetic quality of the human population through genetic manipulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Eugenics

Explanation: 

Eugenics is a field that seeks to improve the genetic composition of a human population by encouraging the reproduction of people with desirable traits (positive eugenics) and discouraging or preventing the reproduction of people with undesirable traits (negative eugenics).

Positive Eugenics

The goal is to increase the prevalence of desirable traits in the population over generations.

This can be encouraged through various means such as:

  • Financial and political stimuli
  • Targeted demographic analyses
  • In vitro fertilisation
  • Egg transplants
  • Gene cloning

 

Negative Eugenics

The objective is to reduce the frequency of hereditary disease and disability in the community.

This could involve measures such as:

  • Abortions
  • Sterilizations
  • Other methods of family planning

 

Euthenics (Option A) focuses on improving human health and well-being by enhancing environmental and living conditions rather than altering genetic traits.

This includes-

  • prevention and removal of contagious diseases and parasites,
  • environmentalism,
  • education regarding home economics,
  • sanitation and housing (environmental manipulation).

 

Epigenetics (Option C) : Study of changes in gene expression caused by mechanisms other than changes in the underlying DNA sequence.


Ethnology (Option D): Scientific study of the origins and cultures of different races and ethnicities.

questions.text: Which statement does not align with the Hardy-Weinberg Principle?

choices.text: Allele frequencies vary within a species
Presence of random mating and a large population size

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Allele frequencies vary within a species

Explanation: 

  • The Hardy-Weinberg law states that the genotype and allele frequencies remain constant in a population from generation to generation in the absence of evolutionary forces.
  • It assumes that the population is stable and large, random mating occurs, no mutations affect the gene pool, no migration occurs, and natural selection does not act on the alleles.

 

Hardy-Weinberg Principle: provides a quantitative framework for predicting genotype frequencies based on allele frequencies in a non-evolving population.

  • The formula is expressed as: p2+2pq+q2= 1, where p and q represent the frequencies of two alleles (denoted as dominant and recessive), and p2, 2pq,and q2 represent the frequencies of the three possible genotypes.
  • Frequency of homozygous dominant genotype + frequency of homozygous recessive genotype + frequency of heterozygous genotype = 1

questions.text: Which of the following factors can lead to deviations from the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

Explanation: 

The Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium describes an idealised situation where population and gene pool remain constant over generations in the absence of evolutionary influences.

Deviations from this equilibrium can occur due to various factors:

  • Non-random mating (assortative mating)
  • New mutations - Introducing new alleles into the gene pool
  • Genetic drift - Random changes in allele frequencies due to chance events
  • Gene flow -
  • Natural selection - mortality selection, fecundity selection
  • Small population
  • Migration
  • Dynamic populations

questions.text: Which of the following best describes prospective genetic counselling?

choices.text: Identifying heterozygous individuals for a specific defect through screening
Seeking genetic advice after a hereditary disorder has already occurred in the family
Discussing options such as contraception and termination of pregnancy based on genetic information
Counselling individuals with congenital anomalies, mental retardation, or inborn errors of metabolism

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Identifying heterozygous individuals for a specific defect through screening

Explanation: 

Prospective genetic counselling involves identifying individuals who are carriers (heterozygous) through screening processes for a genetic defect before any disorder occurs.

Genetic counselling is a process that involves evaluating family history and genetic information to provide individuals and families with information about their genetic health and risks. It can be prospective or retrospective.


 

Prospective Genetic Counselling

Retrospective Genetic Counselling

Seeking genetic advice before the occurrence of a hereditary disorder

Seeking genetic advice after a hereditary disorder has occurred (Option B)

Identify heterozygous individuals and explain the risk of having affected children if they marry another carrier,

Prevention and risk assessment.

Methods suggested:

  • Contraception (Option C)
  • Pregnancy termination (Option C)
  • Sterilisation

Applications: Sickle cell anaemia, thalassemia

Applications: Counselling about Congenital abnormalities, Mental retardation, inborn errors of metabolism, psychiatric illnesses. (Option D)

Prevention and risk assessment

Provide guidance and management after the disorder has manifested
